instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2901: What is 820-2901? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL>=11.98v
<SIGNAL>PP12_G3H</SIGNAL>= 11.98
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>= 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> =4.8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>=not present 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>= not present 

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> on the other hand has
Vin pin 17 is 12v
En1 pin 12 is 3.94v
En2 is not present 
PmslpðŸ˜ŸðŸ˜ŸðŸ˜Ÿ
Pls what can I do

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL>.
If nothing, check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is stuck on 3V, no drop pulse noted?

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
You waste time, if don't post important information in your threads.
Don't you know yet which should be the <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> voltage?
Nothing can move on the board, if <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> stay low; basic checkings...

You may have SMC problem.
Bad PCH can also pull down <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
Sorry this the first time am working on an iMac with such issues. And you are here to put me through, my experience is not that deep. 
so I should change smc

threads.title: iMac <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
Power on sequence is the same, no matters iMac, or MacBook.
You should take notes from the forum and gain time this way.

Check <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> (3 OF 3) signals and voltages (page 45).
